kegginaq: face; sharp edge of knife blade
yuar-: to look for something; to miss someone)
qanemciq: story; account of what has happened
ava(ni): over there (extended); in the area which speaker has gone past
umyuaqerte-: to remember or recall (it); to have (it) come to ones mind
angu-: to catch (game animal) after chasing it; to be old enough to hav
kiatae: area away from exit (from pos- sessor)
inar-: lie down, go to bed, recline
kelutmun: up the slope away from a body of water
pula-: to go forward through a thicket, clouds, darkness
tamaa(ni): there, near listener or in context of situation spoken about (extended)
aqvai-: to go get food from the fishcamp
nayur-: to watch out for or look after
piciatun: any old way; of various un- specified kinds
manar-: to fish (with hook and line, as through the ice); to catch by hooking
tepae: odor; fish head aged for eating
man'a: this, the one near the speaker
qessa-: to not feel like doing anything
uluaq: semi-lunar knife, traditional Eskimo-style woman's knife
caaqarni: at certain times for him, them, us, etc
paugna: that one up the slope (ex- tended)
ketetmun: down the slope toward a body of water
quyavike-: to be thankful to him, to thank him
arulair-: to stop (moving from one place to another)
egamaarrluk: partially dried fish boiled for eating
igvar-: to appear, to come into view, to have (it) come into one's view
muir-: to be full; to fill full
pegte-: to release, to let go of
kiiryug-: to be hot, to feel hot (person)
iqmig-: to chew tobacco; to hold (it) in ones mouth
nala-: to die (plant mostly; sometimes animal or human); to get numb
imna: that one, the aforementioned one known to both speaker and listener (obscured)
makte-: to get up; to set upright
tegumiar-: to take something in one's hand(s)
makumiu: localite; resident of this village (here where we are)
ugna: that one toward the exit; one downriver, (restricted)
naanguar-: to play with toys; to play by pretending
caaqameng: at certain times for him, them, us, etc
iluteqe-: to cry due to emotion (grief, joy not pain)
cavte-: to intentionally touch or feel (it) with ones hand(s)
uame-: to play around, to waste time
erte-: for day to break, for dawn to come
ketae: area in front (of building), area toward river
tamana: that one there, near listener or in context of situation spoken about (extended)
Yugcetun: in the Yup'ik Eskimo lan- guage
arenqiapaa: too bad, but that's the way it is
quser-: to cough; to have a cold
icivaq: a few days or weeks ago
upag-: to move; to change one's place of residence; to move to or from fishcamp
nayagaq: younger sister of male, younger female parallel cousin of male
taqe-: to quit; to stop; to finish
qavartar-: to camp out; to spend the night
maaten: just when ... (and saw that), 10 and behold
anglanaite-: to not be fun; to not be enjoyable
yugte-: to kill a person (intentionally or accidentally)
ulug-: to soften (it - usually a skin) by means ofa circular crumpling motion of the hands
ukurraq: daughter-in-law, sister-in-law in the sense of ones brothers wife
tage-: to go up (the slope); to go up from the water
murilke-: to be attentive; to watch over (him or it)
ule-: for tide to come in; to rise (of water level, dough, etc.)
ipgiate-: to be dull (of knife, needle, etc.)
tuyuun: thing possessor has sent, gift sent
un'a: that one down below; that one down the slope, (extended)
tallirpik: right hand; one on the right side
nunate-: to visit (them) (away from one's own village), to vacation
icivaqu: a few days or weeks from now
unegna: that one down river; that one toward the exit, (extended)
paivte-: to set (it) out for use or view
uive-: to go around (it) (in a circle); to revolve
takar-: shy; respectful; ill at ease; intimidated
yuu-: to get out (from boat, sled, etc.), to take out (from boat, sled, container); to take off (garment)
iqsuq: left hand, one on the left side
iqsuk: left hand, one on the left side
anger-: to acquiesce (to his wish), to agree
ayuqe-: to be like (something), to resemble (something), to be alike
nengauk: son-in-law, brother-in-law in the sense of ones sister's husband, also perhaps uncle by mar- riage
nepte-: to stick on something; to cling to something
kumlate-: to be cold (liquid, solid, or body part)
kiugna: that one in there; that one upriver, (restricted)
nuyiur-: to comb or otherwise fix one's hair
inqe-: to talk to a baby with cooing words
uu-: (of cooking) (trans. with impersonal subject = infruns.) Chap. 15
mingqii-: to make a coiled grass basket
tegu-: to take into ones hands; to pick up
upte-: to get ready; to get (him/her) ready
qasgiq: kashim, old-time men's com- munal house; steambath house
mertar-: to get water (from a well, river, etc.)
qaugna: that one in there; that one upriver, (extended)
arenqiate-: for there to be an unfortunate, undesirable, but irremediable situation
irniange-: to get a child; to have a baby
kingu: rear (of boat or other vehicle), time after
waqaa: hello, what's up?, what do you want?
nange-: to become used up; to use up
imkuciq: a thing like the aforementioned one which we know bout, what-cha-ma-call-it, thig-a-ma-jig
pitaq: caught thing (animal, bird, etc. thing caught by possessor
arcik: male's wife's sister's husband, brother-in-law (in that narrow sense)
pai: opening, mouth (of river, den, bottle, etc.)
asme-: to break in two (of a relatively long object)
kan'a: that one down below; that one down the slope, (restricted)
assili-: to enjoy oneself, to have a good time
augna: that one over there (extended); the one going away from speaker or which speaker has gone past
evcug-: to shake or brush snow or dirt off oneself or another
itume-: to fall apart, to break into pieces
inqutaq: the particular cooing words used with a certain baby
initaq: horizontal pole on which fish is hung to dry
kelu: area behind (building) , area back from river
nacig-: to be unhappy (crying usually) because of being left behind (by him)
uitate-: to leave it alone; to let it be
neryar-: to eat berries as one picks them
kiarte-: to look around (for it), to scan ones surroundings (for it)
payugte-: to give a gift of food to (him)
tegumiaq: a thing one is taking along in his hand(s)
qaner-: to talk, to saying something; to say (it)
uputaar-: to say unfavorable things about (him/her), out of that person's hearing
manaq: fish hook; hook, line and rod for fishing
caaqamta: at certain times for him, them, us, etc
takuyar-: to look back over one's shoulder (at)
anglani-: to enjoy; to watch with enjoyment; to have fun
anglanarqe-: to be fun; to be enjoyable
ekvik: cut bank of a river, cliff
uatmun: toward the door from inside the building; toward downriver
eke-: to get in; to put it in
kiatmun: toward further into the build- ing; toward upriver
qamna: that one in there; that one upriver, (obscured)
uita-: to stay, live, reside, be located
nallae: period of time or space (corre- sponding to grammatical possessor)
asgur-: to go against (the current), to go upriver
kumlaneq: frozen fish which is eaten in that state
qivir-: to put ingredients into (it), add something to (it)
petug-: to fasten it (dog, boat, etc.) to something immovable
minaq: food not eaten, left for another person
aipaq: partner, companion, spouse, other of a pair
pi-: to go; to do (to); to say (to)
puge-: to surface, to come to the sur- face
tua-i-ngunrituq: it isn't the end; we'll meet again
kass'arte-: to go to Bethel or Anchorage to shop
mingug-: to put ointment on (it); to paint; to spread butter on (it)
